neighbors.name: Sara Lee Corp
neighbors.claims: While the parcel remains associated with Sara Lee Corp in county records, the facility was acquired by Tyson Foods, which invested $59.7 million in 2017-2018 to construct a 164,000-square-foot expansion and add 114 jobs [Tyson Foods](https://www.tysonfoods.com/news/news-releases/2017/7/tyson-foods-invest-59-million-expand-pennsylvania-distribution-center). In May 2025, Tyson Foods entered an agreement to sell this Pottsville facility (along with three others) to Lineage Logistics, a real estate investment trust specializing in cold storage, for $247 million [Provisioner Online](https://www.provisioneronline.com/articles/118735-lineage-acquires-tyson-foods-cold-storage-warehouses-for-247-million). The facility serves as a major cold storage and distribution hub for the Northeast region [Tyson Foods](https://www.tysonfoods.com/news/news-releases/2017/7/tyson-foods-invest-59-million-expand-pennsylvania-distribution-center).
neighbors.influence_justification: Major regional employer; critical infrastructure asset (cold storage) transitioning to Lineage Logistics, the world's largest cold storage REIT.

approach_recommendations.engage: Establish contact with incoming Lineage Logistics facility management; ensure project construction does not impede heavy truck traffic or 24/7 distribution operations.

neighbors.profile_summary: Former Sara Lee distribution center, expanded by Tyson Foods, and currently transitioning to ownership by Lineage Logistics as of 2025.

citations.claim: Tyson Foods invested $59.7 million in 2017-2018 to expand the facility by 164,000 square feet and add 114 jobs.
citations.title: Tyson Foods to Invest $59 Million to Expand Pennsylvania Distribution Center

citations.claim: In May 2025, Tyson Foods agreed to sell the Pottsville facility to Lineage Logistics as part of a $247 million deal.
citations.title: Lineage acquires Tyson Foods cold storage warehouses for $247 million

neighbors.name: Schuylkill Economic Dev Corp
neighbors.claims: Schuylkill Economic Development Corp (SEDCO) is a nonprofit organization founded in 1952 to drive industrial development, currently led by President Frank Zukas [City of Pottsville](http://www.pottsvillepa.gov/html/cp5.htm). SEDCO developed and manages the 2,000-acre Highridge Business Park, home to major distribution centers including Lowe's and Wegmans [SEDCO](https://www.sed-co.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/Highridge_Lot-6_SEDCO-2023.pdf). In February 2026, SEDCO received $3.1 million in state funding to prepare 'Lot 12' in Foster Township for a proposed 262,400 square foot shell building [Shenandoah Sentinel](https://shensentinel.com/news/sedco-receiving-3m-in-state-assistance-to-prepare-site-in-highridge-industrial-park/). Zukas has explicitly advocated for development projects by highlighting their tax revenue benefits for local school districts and townships [Shenandoah Sentinel](https://shensentinel.com/news/mahanoy-township-hears-feedback-and-pushback-as-it-considers-zoning-amendment-courts-two-warehouse-developers/).
neighbors.influence_justification: Primary economic development agency in the county; controls large tracts of developable land; secures millions in state funding; strong political connections.

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage SEDCO President Frank Zukas immediately. Position the project as a complementary economic driver that aligns with their mission of revitalizing industrial land and increasing the tax base.

neighbors.profile_summary: County-level economic development corporation actively developing industrial sites and supporting large-scale infrastructure projects.

citations.claim: SEDCO was founded in 1952 and is led by President Frank Zukas.
citations.title: City of Pottsville Economic Development

citations.claim: Manages Highridge Business Park and lists major tenants like Lowe's and Wegmans.
citations.title: Highridge Business Park Lot 6 Flyer

citations.claim: Received $3.1 million in February 2026 to prepare Lot 12 for a new shell building.
citations.title: SEDCO receiving $3M in state assistance to prepare site in Highridge Industrial Park

citations.claim: Frank Zukas advocates for development based on tax revenue generation for schools and municipalities.
citations.title: Mahanoy Township hears feedback as it courts warehouse developers

neighbors.name: Reading Anthracite Co
neighbors.claims: Reading Anthracite Company, led by the Rich family, owns approximately 16,000 acres of real estate in the region [PA Senate GOP](https://community.pasenategop.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/56/2022/10/anthracite.pdf). The company is actively developing renewable energy on its former mine lands, including a solar farm in West Mahanoy Township approved in October 2023 [Shenandoah Sentinel](https://shensentinel.com/news/reading-anthracite-gets-first-solar-farm-approved/) and a 25-acre solar facility in Schuylkill Township approved the same month [Times News](https://www.tnonline.com/20231020/schuylkill-twp-approves-solar-panels-on-coal-land/). Additionally, Reading Anthracite has partnered with CRG Acquisition LLC to propose a massive logistics hub in Foster Township featuring six warehouses, including one as large as 1.6 million square feet [Shenandoah Sentinel](https://shensentinel.com/news/foster-reviewing-proposed-plans-for-six-large-warehouses/).
neighbors.influence_justification: Largest private landowner in the region; actively developing utility-scale solar and industrial warehousing; politically influential via the Rich family.

approach_recommendations.engage: Treat as a peer developer. Explore potential for shared infrastructure or interconnection collaboration, as they are actively deploying solar on their own adjacent/nearby holdings.

neighbors.profile_summary: Legacy mining company actively pivoting to renewable energy development and large-scale industrial warehousing on its vast land holdings.

citations.claim: Owns approximately 16,000 acres of real estate in the region.
citations.title: Environmental and Economic Impacts of the Anthracite Industry

citations.claim: Received zoning approval for a solar farm in West Mahanoy Township in October 2023.
citations.title: Reading Anthracite gets first solar farm approved

citations.claim: Secured approval for a 25-acre solar facility in Schuylkill Township in October 2023.
citations.title: Schuylkill Twp. approves solar panels on coal land

citations.claim: Proposed six large warehouses in Foster Township, with the largest being 1.6 million square feet.
citations.title: Foster reviewing proposed plans for six large warehouses
